event.doc_name: Class Action Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief

evidence.text: In April 2025, the Department of Justice’s Office of Justice Programs abruptly and summarily terminated more than 370 multi-year cooperative agreements and grants awarding more than $820 million in essential funding.
evidence.source_document: Class Action Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief

evidence.text: OJP sent a form email to Plaintiffs and other grantees, offering the same unsupported explanation that Plaintiffs’ 'awards no longer effectuate[] the program goals or agency priorities.'
evidence.source_document: Class Action Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief

add_extracted.value: OJP terminated 370+ multi-year cooperative agreements and grants totaling $820 million in April 2025 with no prior notice, citing 'no longer effectuate[] the program goals or agency priorities' as the sole justification

evidence.text: These include grants addressing violence reduction and intervention, policing and prosecution, victims’ services, juvenile justice and child protection, substance use and mental health treatment, corrections and reentry, justice system enhancements, research and evaluation, and other state- and local-level public safety functions.
evidence.source_document: Class Action Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief

add_extracted.value: Plaintiffs' grant programs address violence reduction, policing, victims' services, juvenile justice, substance use/mental health treatment, corrections/reentry, justice system enhancements, and research/evaluation

evidence.text: As a direct result of OJP’s unlawful termination of Plaintiffs’ grants, services to many of these populations have abruptly ceased. Staff have been laid off without meaningful alternatives for employment, and many more staff will soon be laid off without funding.
evidence.source_document: Class Action Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief

evidence.text: Deaf and hard-of-hearing victims of crimes lost access to free sign language interpretation services... This program has served more than 4,000 individuals.
evidence.source_document: Class Action Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief

add_extracted.value: Termination caused immediate harm including staff layoffs, program cancellations, and loss of critical services to vulnerable populations (e.g., Deaf victims, hate crime survivors, youth at risk of violence)

evidence.text: For individuals who rely on FORCE Detroit for safety planning, relocation assistance, employment support, or therapy referrals, this termination of funding is devasting. This includes individuals like Carol, a single mother and dedicated nurse who, after offering temporary shelter to a friend, became the target of escalating violence, culminating in the tragic shooting of her stepdaughter.
evidence.source_document: Class Action Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief

evidence.text: At least 40 victims of hate crimes will lose the opportunity to participate in Stop AAPI Hate’s healing support programs.
evidence.source_document: Class Action Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief

evidence.text: As a direct result of OJP’s terminations, CCYJ has had to end a project to build organizational and administrative capacity of CBOs... As result of this grant termination, as many as 65 young people may no longer be able to access these services.
evidence.source_document: Class Action Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief

add_extracted.value: Specific examples of harm: Carol's case (nurse whose stepdaughter was shot), 40+ hate crime victims losing healing support, 65 youth losing gang intervention services
